item.title: A startup in Mongolia translated my book
item.description: A 30-person startup called Nasha Tech translated The Software Engineer's Guidebook for the benefit of their company and the Mongolian tech ecosystem.

item.title: The Pulse: Cloudflare takes down half the internet – but shares a great postmortem
item.description: A database permissions change ended up knocking Cloudflare’s proxy offline. Pinpointing the root cause was tricky – but Cloudflare shared a detailed postmortem. Also: announcing The Pragmatic Summit

item.title: Four years on writing a tech book: pitching to a publisher
item.description: In 2019, I decided to write a book about software engineering. As an experienced software engineer and manager, I had the topic clear in my head, and assumed the whole project would take between six and 12 months in writing and publishing it.

item.title: The Pulse: Amazon layoffs – AI or economy to blame?
item.description: Amazon is doing more mass layoffs, claiming it wants to be more nimble. But are job losses really about US economic fears, and how Amazon’s retail business will be affected?

item.title: Comparing interviews at 8 large tech companies
item.description: Puneet Patwari applied to 8 major tech companies, and received 6 offers. He compares his interview experiences at Meta, Amazon, Uber, and 5 other workplaces

item.title: New trend: programming by kicking off parallel AI agents
item.description: More devs are experimenting with kicking off coding agents in parallel

item.title: What caused the large AWS outage?
item.description: On Monday, a major AWS outage hit thousands of sites & apps, and even a Premier League soccer game. An overview of what caused this high-profile, global outage

item.title: Creative ways to fund open source projects
item.description: “Open source maintenance fee” trialed by Wix Toolset, while the creator of uv offers paid, enterprise-only features for larger companies.

item.title: New trend: extreme hours at AI startups
item.description: Pulling 80+ hour work weeks – including weekends – is becoming the norm across AI startups, and is unlikely to stop while AI is so hot.

item.title: Cursor makes developers less effective?
item.description: A study into the workflows of experienced developers found that devs who use Cursor for bugfixes are around 19% slower than devs who use no AI tools at all. One possible takeaway is that AI tools can be harder work than we’re led to believe.

item.title: The Pulse: Section 174 is reversed! Mostly, that is
item.description: Finally, relief: tax regulation hurting the US tech industry is striked off for good - for the most part, that is.

item.title: Software engineering with LLMs in 2025: temperature check
item.description:
How are devs using AI tools at Big Tech and startups, and what do they actually think of them? This was the topic of my annual conference talk, in June 2025, in London, at LDX3 by LeadDev.

To research, I talked with devs at:

  • AI

item.title: Builder.ai did not “fake AI with 700 engineers”
item.description: The claim that the AI startup “faked AI” with hundreds of engineers went viral – and I also fell for it, initially. The reality is much more sobering: Builder.ai built a code generator on top of Claude and other LLMs; it did not build a so-called “Mechanical Turk.”

item.title: Stack overflow is almost dead
item.description: Today, Stack overflow has almost as few questions asked per month, as when it launched back in 2009. A recap of its slow, then rapid, downfall.

item.title: Tech hiring: is this an inflection point?
item.description: We might be seeing the end of remote coding interviews as we know them, and a return of in-person interviews, trial days and longer trial periods. Could hiring be returning to pre-pandemic norms?
